trans-unit.source: Get Started with Offline Data Sync in Mobile Services (iOS) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Get Started with Offline Data Sync in Mobile Services (iOS) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Azure Mobile Services to cache and sync offline data in your iOS application
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Azure Mobile Services to cache and sync offline data in your iOS application

trans-unit.source: Get Started with Offline Data Sync in Mobile Services
trans-unit.target: Get Started with Offline Data Sync in Mobile Services

trans-unit.source: Offline sync allows you to view, add, or modify data in a mobile app even when there is no network connection.
trans-unit.target: Offline sync allows you to view, add, or modify data in a mobile app even when there is no network connection.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you'll learn how your app can automatically store changes in a local offline database and sync those changes whenever it's back online.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you'll learn how your app can automatically store changes in a local offline database and sync those changes whenever it's back online.

trans-unit.source: Offline sync has several advantages:
trans-unit.target: Offline sync has several advantages:

trans-unit.source: Improves app responsiveness by caching server data locally on device
trans-unit.target: Improves app responsiveness by caching server data locally on device

trans-unit.source: Makes apps resilient against intermittent network connectivity
trans-unit.target: Makes apps resilient against intermittent network connectivity

trans-unit.source: Allows you to create and modify data even with little or no connectivity
trans-unit.target: Allows you to create and modify data even with little or no connectivity

trans-unit.source: Syncs data across multiple devices
trans-unit.target: Syncs data across multiple devices

trans-unit.source: Detects conflicts when same record is modified by two devices
trans-unit.target: Detects conflicts when same record is modified by two devices

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] To complete this tutorial, you need an Azure account.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] To complete this tutorial, you need an Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can sign up for an Azure trial and get [free mobile services that you can keep using even after your trial ends](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/details/mobile-services/).
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can sign up for an Azure trial and get [free mobile services that you can keep using even after your trial ends](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/details/mobile-services/).

trans-unit.source: For details, see [Azure Free Trial](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/?WT.mc_id=AE564AB28 target="_blank").
trans-unit.target: For details, see [Azure Free Trial](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/?WT.mc_id=AE564AB28 target="_blank").

trans-unit.source: This tutorial is based on the [Mobile Services Quick Start tutorial], which you must complete first.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial is based on the [Mobile Services Quick Start tutorial], which you must complete first.

trans-unit.source: Let's first review the code related to offline sync already in the Quick Start.
trans-unit.target: Let's first review the code related to offline sync already in the Quick Start.

trans-unit.source: Review Mobile Services Sync Code
trans-unit.target: Review Mobile Services Sync Code

trans-unit.source: Azure Mobile Services offline sync allows end users to interact with a local database when the network is not accessible.
trans-unit.target: Azure Mobile Services offline sync allows end users to interact with a local database when the network is not accessible.

trans-unit.source: To use these features in your app, you initialize the sync context of `MSClient` and reference a local store.
trans-unit.target: To use these features in your app, you initialize the sync context of `MSClient` and reference a local store.

trans-unit.source: Then reference your table through the `MSSyncTable` interface.
trans-unit.target: Then reference your table through the `MSSyncTable` interface.

trans-unit.source: In **QSTodoService.m**, notice the type of member `syncTable` is `MSSyncTable`.
trans-unit.target: In **QSTodoService.m**, notice the type of member `syncTable` is `MSSyncTable`.

trans-unit.source: Offline sync uses this instead of `MSTable`.
trans-unit.target: Offline sync uses this instead of `MSTable`.

trans-unit.source: When a sync table is used, all operations go to the local store and are synchronized with the remote service only with explicit push and pull operations.
trans-unit.target: When a sync table is used, all operations go to the local store and are synchronized with the remote service only with explicit push and pull operations.

trans-unit.source: To get a reference to a sync table, use the method `syncTableWithName`.
trans-unit.target: To get a reference to a sync table, use the method `syncTableWithName`.

trans-unit.source: To remove offline sync functionality, use `tableWithName` instead.
trans-unit.target: To remove offline sync functionality, use `tableWithName` instead.

trans-unit.source: In **QSTodoService.m**, before table operations are performed, the local store is initialized in `QSTodoService.init`:
trans-unit.target: In **QSTodoService.m**, before table operations are performed, the local store is initialized in `QSTodoService.init`:

trans-unit.source: This creates a local store using the `MSCoreDataStore` interface.
trans-unit.target: This creates a local store using the `MSCoreDataStore` interface.

trans-unit.source: You may provide a different local store by implementing the `MSSyncContextDataSource` protocol.
trans-unit.target: You may provide a different local store by implementing the `MSSyncContextDataSource` protocol.

trans-unit.source: The first parameter of `initWithDelegate` specifies a conflict handler, but since we've passed `nil`, we get the default conflict handler which fails on any conflict.
trans-unit.target: The first parameter of `initWithDelegate` specifies a conflict handler, but since we've passed `nil`, we get the default conflict handler which fails on any conflict.

trans-unit.source: For details on how to implement a custom conflict handler, see [Handling Conflicts with Offline Support for Mobile Services].
trans-unit.target: For details on how to implement a custom conflict handler, see [Handling Conflicts with Offline Support for Mobile Services].

trans-unit.source: In **QSTodoService.m**, `syncData` first pushes new changes, and then calls `pullData` to get data from the remote service.
trans-unit.target: In **QSTodoService.m**, `syncData` first pushes new changes, and then calls `pullData` to get data from the remote service.

trans-unit.source: In `syncData`, we first call `pushWithCompletion` on the sync context.
trans-unit.target: In `syncData`, we first call `pushWithCompletion` on the sync context.

trans-unit.source: This method is a member of `MSSyncContext` -- rather than the sync table itself -- because it pushes changes across all tables.
trans-unit.target: This method is a member of `MSSyncContext` -- rather than the sync table itself -- because it pushes changes across all tables.

trans-unit.source: Only records that are modified in some way locally -- through creation, update, or delete operations -- are sent to the server.
trans-unit.target: Only records that are modified in some way locally -- through creation, update, or delete operations -- are sent to the server.

trans-unit.source: At the end of `syncData`, we call the helper `pullData`.
trans-unit.target: At the end of `syncData`, we call the helper `pullData`.

trans-unit.source: In this example, the push operation is not strictly necessary.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the push operation is not strictly necessary.

trans-unit.source: If there are changes pending in the sync context for the table that is doing a push operation, pull always issues a push first.
trans-unit.target: If there are changes pending in the sync context for the table that is doing a push operation, pull always issues a push first.

trans-unit.source: However, if you have more than one sync table, call push explicitly to have consistency across tables.
trans-unit.target: However, if you have more than one sync table, call push explicitly to have consistency across tables.

trans-unit.source: Next in **QSTodoService.m**, `pullData` gets new data that matches a query.
trans-unit.target: Next in **QSTodoService.m**, `pullData` gets new data that matches a query.

trans-unit.source: `pullData` calls `MSSyncTable.pullWithQuery` to retrieve remote data and store it locally.
trans-unit.target: `pullData` calls `MSSyncTable.pullWithQuery` to retrieve remote data and store it locally.

trans-unit.source: `pullWithQuery` also allows you to specify a query to filter the records you wish to retrieve.
trans-unit.target: `pullWithQuery` also allows you to specify a query to filter the records you wish to retrieve.

trans-unit.source: In this example, the query just retrieves all records in the remote `TodoItem` table.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the query just retrieves all records in the remote `TodoItem` table.

trans-unit.source: The second parameter to `pullWithQuery` is a query ID for _incremental sync_.
trans-unit.target: The second parameter to `pullWithQuery` is a query ID for _incremental sync_.

trans-unit.source: Incremental sync retrieves only those records modified since the last sync, using the record's `UpdatedAt` timestamp, called `ms_updatedAt` in the local store.
trans-unit.target: Incremental sync retrieves only those records modified since the last sync, using the record's `UpdatedAt` timestamp, called `ms_updatedAt` in the local store.

trans-unit.source: The query ID is descriptive string that is unique for each logical query in your app.
trans-unit.target: The query ID is descriptive string that is unique for each logical query in your app.

trans-unit.source: To opt-out of incremental sync, pass `nil` as the query ID.
trans-unit.target: To opt-out of incremental sync, pass `nil` as the query ID.

trans-unit.source: This is inefficient since it will retrieve all records on every pull operation.
trans-unit.target: This is inefficient since it will retrieve all records on every pull operation.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] To remove records from the device local store when they have been deleted in your mobile service database, enable [Soft Delete].
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] To remove records from the device local store when they have been deleted in your mobile service database, enable [Soft Delete].

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, your app should periodically call `MSSyncTable.purgeWithQuery` to purge the local store.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, your app should periodically call `MSSyncTable.purgeWithQuery` to purge the local store.

trans-unit.source: In **QSTodoService.m**, the methods `addItem` and `completeItem` invoke `syncData` after modifying data.
trans-unit.target: In **QSTodoService.m**, the methods `addItem` and `completeItem` invoke `syncData` after modifying data.

trans-unit.source: In **QSTodoListViewController.m**, the method `refresh` also invokes `syncData` so that the UI displays the latest data on every refresh and at launch (`init` calls `refresh`.)
trans-unit.target: In **QSTodoListViewController.m**, the method `refresh` also invokes `syncData` so that the UI displays the latest data on every refresh and at launch (`init` calls `refresh`.)

trans-unit.source: Because the app calls `syncData` whenever you modify data, the app assumes you are online whenever you edit data in the app.
trans-unit.target: Because the app calls `syncData` whenever you modify data, the app assumes you are online whenever you edit data in the app.

trans-unit.source: Review Core Data Model
trans-unit.target: Review Core Data Model

trans-unit.source: When using the Core Data offline store, you need to define particular tables and fields in your data model.
trans-unit.target: When using the Core Data offline store, you need to define particular tables and fields in your data model.

trans-unit.source: The sample app already includes a data model with the right format.
trans-unit.target: The sample app already includes a data model with the right format.

trans-unit.source: In this section we walk through these tables and how they are used.
trans-unit.target: In this section we walk through these tables and how they are used.

trans-unit.source: Open **QSDataModel.xcdatamodeld**.
trans-unit.target: Open **QSDataModel.xcdatamodeld**.

trans-unit.source: There are four tables defined, three used by the SDK and one for the todo items themselves:
trans-unit.target: There are four tables defined, three used by the SDK and one for the todo items themselves:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The Mobile Services SDK reserves column names that begin with "**`ms_`**".
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The Mobile Services SDK reserves column names that begin with "**`ms_`**".

trans-unit.source: Do not use this prefix on anything other than system columns.
trans-unit.target: Do not use this prefix on anything other than system columns.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, your column names will be modified when using the remote service.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, your column names will be modified when using the remote service.

trans-unit.source: When using the offline sync feature, you must define the system tables as shown below.
trans-unit.target: When using the offline sync feature, you must define the system tables as shown below.

trans-unit.source: System Tables
trans-unit.target: System Tables

trans-unit.target: MS_TableOperations

trans-unit.target: Attribute

trans-unit.target: Type

trans-unit.target: id (required)

trans-unit.source: Change Sync Behavior of App
trans-unit.target: Change Sync Behavior of App

trans-unit.source: In this section, you modify the app so that it does not sync on app start, or when inserting and updating items, but only when the refresh gesture is performed.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you modify the app so that it does not sync on app start, or when inserting and updating items, but only when the refresh gesture is performed.

trans-unit.source: In **QSTodoListViewController.m**, change `viewDidLoad` to remove the call to `[self refresh]` at the end of the method.
trans-unit.target: In **QSTodoListViewController.m**, change `viewDidLoad` to remove the call to `[self refresh]` at the end of the method.

trans-unit.source: Now, the data will not be synced with the server on app start, but instead will be only stored locally.
trans-unit.target: Now, the data will not be synced with the server on app start, but instead will be only stored locally.

trans-unit.source: In **QSTodoService.m**, modify `addItem` so that it doesn't sync after the item is inserted.
trans-unit.target: In **QSTodoService.m**, modify `addItem` so that it doesn't sync after the item is inserted.

trans-unit.source: Remove the `self syncData` block and replace it with the following:
trans-unit.target: Remove the `self syncData` block and replace it with the following:

trans-unit.source: Similarly, again in **QSTodoService.m**, in `completeItem`, remove the block for `self syncData` and replace with the following:
trans-unit.target: Similarly, again in **QSTodoService.m**, in `completeItem`, remove the block for `self syncData` and replace with the following:

trans-unit.source: Test App
trans-unit.target: Test App

trans-unit.source: In this section, you will turn of Wi-Fi in the simulator to create an offline scenario.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you will turn of Wi-Fi in the simulator to create an offline scenario.

trans-unit.source: When you add data items, they will be held in the local Core Data store, but not synced to the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: When you add data items, they will be held in the local Core Data store, but not synced to the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Turn off the internet connection on your Mac.
trans-unit.target: Turn off the internet connection on your Mac.

trans-unit.source: Turning off WiFi in just iOS simulator may not have an effect, since the simulator may still use the host Mac's internet connection, so turn off internet for the computer itself.
trans-unit.target: Turning off WiFi in just iOS simulator may not have an effect, since the simulator may still use the host Mac's internet connection, so turn off internet for the computer itself.

trans-unit.source: This simulates an offline scenario.
trans-unit.target: This simulates an offline scenario.

trans-unit.source: Add some todo items or complete some items.
trans-unit.target: Add some todo items or complete some items.

trans-unit.source: Quit the simulator (or forcibly close the app) and restart.
trans-unit.target: Quit the simulator (or forcibly close the app) and restart.

trans-unit.source: Verify that your changes have been persisted.
trans-unit.target: Verify that your changes have been persisted.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the data items are still displayed because they are held in the local Core Data store.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the data items are still displayed because they are held in the local Core Data store.

trans-unit.source: View the contents of the remote TodoItem table.
trans-unit.target: View the contents of the remote TodoItem table.

trans-unit.source: Verify that the new items have _not_ been synced to the server.
trans-unit.target: Verify that the new items have _not_ been synced to the server.

trans-unit.source: For the JavaScript backend, go to the Management Portal, and click the Data tab to view the contents of the `TodoItem` table.
trans-unit.target: For the JavaScript backend, go to the Management Portal, and click the Data tab to view the contents of the `TodoItem` table.

trans-unit.source: For the .NET backend, view the table contents either with a SQL tool such as SQL Server Management Studio, or a REST client such as Fiddler or Postman.
trans-unit.target: For the .NET backend, view the table contents either with a SQL tool such as SQL Server Management Studio, or a REST client such as Fiddler or Postman.

trans-unit.source: Turn on Wi-Fi in the iOS simulator.
trans-unit.target: Turn on Wi-Fi in the iOS simulator.

trans-unit.source: Next, perform the refresh gesture by pulling down the list of items.
trans-unit.target: Next, perform the refresh gesture by pulling down the list of items.

trans-unit.source: You will see a progress spinner and the text "Syncing...".
trans-unit.target: You will see a progress spinner and the text "Syncing...".

trans-unit.source: View the TodoItem data again.
trans-unit.target: View the TodoItem data again.

trans-unit.source: The new and changed TodoItems should now appear.
trans-unit.target: The new and changed TodoItems should now appear.

trans-unit.source: Summary
trans-unit.target: Summary

trans-unit.source: In order to support the offline features of mobile services, you used the `MSSyncTable` interface and initialized `MSClient.syncContext` with a local store.
trans-unit.target: In order to support the offline features of mobile services, you used the `MSSyncTable` interface and initialized `MSClient.syncContext` with a local store.

trans-unit.source: In this case the local store was a Core Data-based database.
trans-unit.target: In this case the local store was a Core Data-based database.

trans-unit.source: When using a Core Data local store, you define several tables with the [correct system properties][Review the Core Data model].
trans-unit.target: When using a Core Data local store, you define several tables with the [correct system properties][Review the Core Data model].

trans-unit.source: The normal operations for mobile services work as if the app is still connected but all the operations occur against the local store.
trans-unit.target: The normal operations for mobile services work as if the app is still connected but all the operations occur against the local store.

trans-unit.source: To synchronize the local store with the server, you used `MSSyncTable.pullWithQuery` and `MSClient.syncContext.pushWithCompletion`:
trans-unit.target: To synchronize the local store with the server, you used `MSSyncTable.pullWithQuery` and `MSClient.syncContext.pushWithCompletion`:
